required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Slow Expansion and Protraction in Cleft Lip and Palate Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of the Treatment Outcome of Cleft Palate Patients Treated With Differential Opening Expander With Slow Protocol and Face Mask

lead_sponsor.agency: Faculty of Dental Medicine for Girls

clinical_study.source: Faculty of Dental Medicine for Girls

brief_summary.textblock: Evaluate the treatment outcome of slow maxillary expansion protocol on patients with cleft lip and palate, using a differential opening expander and face mask which will be measured and recorded by cone beam computed tomography (CBCT).

detailed_description.textblock: Cleft lip and palate are among the most common deformities in children. Cleft patients are usually having orofacial problems as missing or unerupted permanent teeth, alveolar bone defect, speech difficulty. Patients with cleft lip and palate (CLP) commonly have maxillary arch constriction (maxillary hypoplasia) and Class III malocclusions due to deficient of maxillary growth. The upper jaw of patients with cleft palate will be expanded using maxillary Expander with Differential Opening (EDO) which has two screws; one anterior and one posterior. This will be done with slow expansion protocol, which is one 1/4 turn three times weekly. Petit facemask will be used to protract the retracted maxilla. The differences in measurements between before and after treatment will be assessed by cone beam computed tomography (CBCT).

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in 3 dimensions of skull before and after expansion
primary_outcome.description: Full skull Cone Beam Computerized Tomography

arm_group.description: Cleft patients with transverse maxillary constriction and anteroposterior deficiency

intervention.description: The EDO is designed with two expansion screws positioned transversely. When more expansion is required between the canines, the anterior screw can be further activated. Both expansion screws can be activated to open in a parallel configuration. Pivoting corner screws allow for different amounts of expansion without significant risk of binding during activation.
The face mask is anatomical, multi-adjustable, lightweight and an ideal therapeutic alternative for the correction of Class III malocclusion. It consists of forehead cap, chin cap, and cross bar.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All patient age ranges from 8 to 12 years.
- Patients of both sexes.
- Cleft lip and palate patients.
- All the cases showed maxillary arch constriction and deficiency.
- All patients had maxillary permanent first molars.
- Primary lip adhesion and palatal closure.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients had received any surgical assisted rapid maxillary expansion or maxillary protraction of fixed orthodontics before.
- Maxillary dentition unsuitable to bond the expander (less than two dental units beside permanent first molar).
- Absent maxillary permanent first molars.
- Uncooperative patients/parents.

overall_official.affiliation: Lecturer of Orthodontics Department, Faculty of Dental Medicine for Girls, Al-Azhar University

facility.name: Faculty of dental medicine for girls, Al-Azhar University

link.description: Maxillary expander with differential opening vs Hyrax expander: A randomized clinical trial

Maxillary dentoskeletal outcomes of the expander with differential opening and the fan-type expander: a randomized controlled trial. responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Faculty of Dental Medicine for Girls

patient_data.ipd_description: Evaluation of EDO, Slow maxillary expansion and facemask in patients with cleft lip and palate (CLP) using Cone Beam Computed Tomography (CBCT)
